column1: 2$Condition: Manic-Depression$12/15/2016 8:51:21 AM$Reviewer: Kristen8885
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$3$I was hospitalized due to a severe panic attack and the emergency psych doctor prescribed this medication to me.  Mind you I am only on Wellbutrin and Abilify for depression and anxiety.  Not knowing what this was and trusting him I filled the script.  I took one at night as directed when I returned home and within a half hour I dropped a full cup of coffee and almost fell down my steps outside.  My fianc√© literally carried me to bed and I don't remember much afterward.  I brought this to my doctor who in turn said that I should have never been prescribed this and to stop taking it immediately.  Long story short I did not like the way this made me feel incapable of caring for myself or my children so I will not be taking this anymore.  Supposedly this is to be used in emergency situations in the hospital?

column1: 3$Condition: Other$11/1/2016 10:15:41 PM$Reviewer: qwertyuiop
column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $3$2$5$"I am very sensitive to psychotropics
column3: so take this review with a grain of salt.

column1: I started on 40mg
column2: split in morning and evening. I got the shakes and got very tired in the afternoon but not in the evening.

column1: Moved to 40mg at night. Zombie action
Dropped to 20mg at night. Seemed okay for a while. Psychosis was about 90% controlled. Over a few months I felt like I had no energy and I was losing muscle mass and feeling weak.
Doc ordered a testosterone test
column2: it was dangerously low. She order a prolactin and thyroid test. Thyroid was good
column3: prolactin was three times the high normal range.

column1: Tapered off
column2: both testosterone and prolactin levels were back to normal inside a month.

column1: I never got near the therapeutic dose."
4$Condition: Mania associated with Bipolar Disorder$10/27/2016 12:56:40 PM$Reviewer: Cathie
column2: 55-64 on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$5$5$Before taking Geodon I was out of control
column3: I was manic and suicidal. I was hospitalized due to these symptoms and the doctors were talking about ECT treatments but I refused them all together. Since I have been on Geodon I haven't had a bad episode of Mania. I also take Latuda for the depression which has made all the difference. It has been a year now since I started the Geodon and I take 80 MG twice a day and have been under control. I recommend this drug to anyone who has Bipolor 1 if they can tolerate it.

column1: 5$Condition: Schizophrenia$1/7/2016 12:50:28 AM$Reviewer: sadsoul

I went off zeldox cold turkey. my speech was better. my tongue was swollen and that went back to normal. I had hacking coughs choking on my own spit .the spit would go down the wrong way. I did not tell my doctor. I thought things were going fine. I told him that I wasn't taking my pills I am now on latuda. I have had it for about a month. im not sure how I am am to feel

column1: 7$Condition: Other$12/2/2015 9:16:29 PM$Reviewer: qwerty
column2: 45-54 Male  (Patient) $3$3$3$"For psychosis. 20 MG in the evening.

column1: I used to take 20 in the morning also but caused me to shake and become overly tired.
Nighttime dose does not give me this side effect
column2: oddly.

8$Condition: Mania associated with Bipolar Disorder$10/25/2015 5:06:58 PM$Reviewer: Tara
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $4$5$5$I was diagnosed with Bipolar I in 2005 when I had my first manic episode. I came off my medicine (lithium) in 2011 and just had my second manic episode (10/15/15). The attending physician put me on generic Geodon after I told him it was what the doctor's used to get me down in 2005. I had no idea you could use the drug as a maintenance drug. I hated getting my blood drawn while on lithium so I really like Geodon. I'm on 40 mg twice a day but my doctor already mentioned my dose will be increased. I do have restlessness and nausea in the morning but I'll take these side effects over the paranoid depression state I've been in for the last 3 years off medication. I'm really happy with the drug.

column1: 10$Condition: Other$9/5/2015 6:19:04 AM$Reviewer: Greybo
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $5$5$5$I was taking this med for alcoholism.  After my latest trip to the ER then being admitted for 4 days and almost leaving this world
column3: I finally woke up to how serious this really is.  Zipra has helped to pretty much stop all cravings and even makes my stomach turn when I smell it.  I took it twice a day for a week then weaned down to once a day for another week and now I am off of it.  If my cravings come back
column4: I will definitely go to my doctor for a new prescription if it.  Two weeks may not be enough to get me strong enough to go solo yet.  I highly recommend it to others battling alcoholism and are finally ready to make the jump to sobriety.  Something before I could never achieve. My thoughts are clear and it feels so good.  My mood is very good most of the time.  I'm not Mary Poppins
column5: but I'm not a grumpy bear like others times I've quit for even shorter amounts of time. Two weeks and two days today.  Baby steps and this med really has helped me.

column1: 12$Condition: Schizophrenia$8/24/2014 3:57:12 PM$Reviewer: Anne
column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$1$2$"I was prescribed this medicine because I hear voices. It has worked very well
column3: despite having a difficult time transitioning onto it. I have heard some voices
column4: but they are minimal. However
column5: we had to put me on such a high dosage that I was falling asleep in class. Even on a lower dosage
column6: I had to take an hour to two-hour nap every day and could not stay awake for more than thirty minutes in the car. Then we switched to taking it all at night (another rough transition) but I was still low on energy
column7: so we lowered it again.

column1: We are thinking of lowering the dosage once more
column2: but it is incredibly scary gambling with mental illness
column3: especially during the semester. I can only pray I will not hear voices again.

column1: This drug has the worst withdrawal out of every anti-psychotic I have taken. If I miss the time I'm supposed to take it by two hours
column2: or even one
column3: I begin to feel terrible. My pupils dilate significantly during withdrawals. If I miss taking it during a meal and take it on an empty stomach
column4: it does not kick in for at least an hour. It keeps me awake when I have not taken it as well.

column1: Even talking about this medicine makes me feel terrible. I can only hope that I will eventually switch onto another medication without an episode."

31$Condition: Schizophrenia$1/24/2013 8:58:06 PM$Reviewer: Schizobus, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$4$I suffer schizoaffective disorder. I switched from Abilify to Geodon mostly because I could only tolerate a low dose of Abilify, which wasn't providing enough therapeutic value. I now take 60mg of Geodon in the morning with breakfast and 80mg of Geodon in the evening with dinner for a total of 140mg daily. I have been taking over 100mg of Geodon daily for about two years now. Geodon helps prevent my psychosis and balances out my mood. I suffer bad akathisia in the evening a few times a week for a few hours with this drug. Most of the time I just try to sleep when akathisia strikes and I awake feeling better. I sleep a lot on this drug: I usually sleep 5 to 7 hours a night and then another 2 to 4 hours in a nap. I find it crucial to take my doses with a meal, as the oral bioavailability is allegedly reduced in half when consuming the drug without food. I sometimes feel as though I withdraw from the drug if I take my dose off schedule or if I have been unable to consistently take the drug with a meal. The withdrawal begins to manifest in symptoms of anxiety and nausea. I have never been overweight but my weight has fluctuated quite a bit in a range of 40lbs since I started taking antipsychotic drugs. I find Geodon doesn't make me gain so much weight for an antipsychotic but I currently have a BMI of 22. Geodon is probably my favorite neuroleptic of the five that I have tried so far.

column1: 49$Condition: Other$11/1/2010 8:33:10 AM$Reviewer: nootropics
column2: 35-44 Male  (Patient) $5$5$4$Schizoaffective disorder.  Hospitalised against will 6 times due to psychosis and mania.  Medications used since 1997: mood stabilizers- lithium
column3: valproate
column4: lamotrigine; antipsychotics- risperidone
column5: olanzapine
column6: amisulpride
column7: quetiapine
column8: aripiprazole; antidepressants- venlafaxine
column9: fluoxetine
column10: reboxetine
column11: paroxetine
column12: mianserin all under close supervision of treating psychiatrist.  Results of ziprasidone monotherapy: only drug that works particularly for refractory bipolar depression and negative symptoms of schizophrenia.  Concerns over lack of efficacy due to underdosing in clinical practice.  Small side-effect footprint so can be used for maintenance therapy.  Without this drug I would be facing electroconvulsive therapy (ECT).  Currently taking 40mg morning and 120mg night (to better regulate sleep rhythms).  Ziprasidone has unique pharmacodynamic action in that it is like an antidepressant/mood stabilizer/antipsychotic rolled into one (dopamine/serotonin modulator plus serotonin/norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor).  Can adjust dose to achieve required mood stabilization but can over-activate at lower doses (cause mania/hypomania).  Action on alpha 1 adrenoreceptors probably causes the cardiovascular side effects (vasodilation= reduced cardiac output=hypotension=dizziness) but this is minor compared with results.  QT interval overhyped.  Vastly improved energy
column14: mood and thinking.  Previously I had to abort medical studies due to illness.  After 7 years out of work
column15: I have been able to return to study a Masters degree.  Remember people to SLOWLY do anything to do with dosing! (titrate over weeks/months).  Take REGULARLY (same time each day with food
column16: don't miss).  Has no weight gain
column17: good for blood lipids/sugars.  My turnaround in first month was remarkable; like an awakening.  Averaged 5 hours sleep but not manic.  Best I've been for 20 years.  If can't tolerate ziprasidone
column18: next best is aripiprazole.  Try everything else

column2: for someone who goes to bed by 9:00pm every night
column3: I was up until 1:00am all 4 nights

column9: the chest pain I feel is a symptom of a manic episode.  Funny... I NEVER experienced a manic episode in my entire LIFE and it wasn't until I took Geodon that I did.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$4$3$So I just started taking Geodon 40mg at night about 2 weeks ago.  I feel better overall except the first few days I had severe nausea and just didn't feel right.  I know alot of people take it twice a day but I am scared that if I take it in the morning that it will make me super tired.  I was on zyprexa before this and gained a bunch of weight and my total cholesterol and LDL shot through the roof and I wound up in the hospital due to heart palpatations and chest pressure.  I am only 52 and my stress test was negative but that was why my medication was changed.  I have bipolar 2 not 1 and have some hypomania but no full blown manic episodes.   I do feel like my muscles hurt but they also put me on lipitor because of my cholesterol being so high which it wasn't prior to taking zyprexa.  I got really bad tartive dys with abilify and rexalti.  I was smacking all the time like a little old lady with no teeth.  No TD so far with the Geodon but I really want to keep my dose low if I can so that does not happen again.  Ingrezza did nothing for me at all.  I am also on lamictal and effexor and have to take meds for sleep as well or I would be awake 24x7.  I am very hopeful for weight loss on this medication and for my cholesterol to improve. I don't feel as flat and tearful as I did on zyprexa so that is good.  My appetite is much less and I try and drink a Gatoraide or poweraide daily to make sure to get some electolytes in me.  It seems to help.  Anyone else taking it just at night or should I take 20mg twice daily for better effect?  Thoughts...

column1: 170$Condition: Schizophrenia$3/29/2015 7:45:20 AM$Reviewer: wjlesaulnier
column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $2$1$3$"Do NOT let your regular family doctor prescribe you Geodon. Go to the best Psychiatrist you can. 80 % of family (general) doctors receive only cursory training  in prescribing psyco-active meds. They haven't learned the subtle and not so subtle behavioral changes that can occur. I took Geodon (2 -80mg /day) for about five years. While I was taking it I could not see the changes. It did not make me sleepy
column3: drunk
column4: or any other obvious bad symptom. I did not laugh or cry for 5 years.  It's hard to explain but nothing just ""occurred"" to me. List of some of the things that didn't occur to me: proper hygiene
column5: to get new shoes when mine had holes
column6: to clean my house
column7: to eat anything other than peanut butter and jelly sandwiches
column8: to get legal help to save my house when my step-mom passed and by far the worst: I didn't pet my dog or cats during that time and I am a hopeless animal lover. I have 3 college degrees and post-graduate work. One of these degrees is in Psychology. I worked at a mental health facility for two years. If I could have objectively observed myself I would have been shocked. All my family and friends had moved or passed away so there was no-one to observe the changes. By sheer luck my insurance changed and no longer covered Geodon ($400+ per month) so I stopped taking it. Now I'm alive again! I've lived with hallucinations for over twenty years. I don't have ""scary"" ones I just get overwhelmed sometimes which can lead to a panic attack. I have yet to try a med that has an effect on the hallucinations where it is even remotely worth putting up with the usually severe side-effects. People with extremely severe problems to the point where they are living no kind of life might very carefully try lower doses of Geodon. Good luck and God bless.

It has been very effective for me, and I have been very stable while on this medication. I do have to take the Geodon and lamictal at least 2 hours apart, otherwise I have real difficulty sleeping. My doctor can't explain to me why that is, but I simply adjust my schedule if needed. I also exercise regularly, eat a good diet, and see my doctor consistently.

202$Condition: Bipolar I Disorder with Most Recent Episode Mixed$2/5/2014 10:00:28 AM$Reviewer: Noura E, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $4$3$5$I took Geodon for 5 years. I started at 40mg a day and increased it to 160mg a day over the course of a year. For the first few months, it was incredibly difficult. I was completely sedated and would sleep minimum 13-14 hours a day. It was near impossible for me to work let alone take care of my 2 year old son. I had to withdraw from my college courses for a semester and I would fall asleep at work. After a while I started taking it with dinner, and I would sleep through the night and although it was very difficult to wake up in the morning, I was at least able to function during the day. I was much more even temepered and it did control the severe ups and downs, but what I did not like was that my body was addicted to it (whether it was an actual physical addiction or mental addiction, I have no idea,) however, I remember it was a holiday weekend, I had run out of refills and I was awake for 3 days. I felt like I was high on drugs. I literally had an out of body experience during these days and it was difficult. It got to the point, if I didnt take the geodon I wouldn't be able to sleep. I came off of it last February (2013) and was prescribed it again yesterday. Being off of it was not easy and my life was incredibly difficult. The side effects are worth it to me, although this time I will only be using it until I'm at a therapeutic dose of lamictal and keep it between 2-40mg/day.

217$Condition: Bipolar I Disorder with Most Recent Episode Mixed$6/18/2013 7:00:34 PM$Reviewer: Professional with Geodon, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$2$Geodon is a great, stabilizing medication, if you are a professional and want to be productive.  Although, it is not a quick solution. You have to be patient and give it a long time to work.  It does have side effects.  This review tells how I worked around them.  I was on Geodon for my mixed, rapid-cycling bipolar disorder for over seven years.  In combination with Zoloft, it did a wonderful job of containing my up and down cycling.  I also have ADD and, with the Geodon, I was finally able to succeed at finishing my dissertation and continuing as a university professor.  It gave me back my life.  Since my body requires more medicine dosage than normal, I was on a mega dose.  I had to take a separate medicine to control the twitches, but that worked.  I am not married, but could imagine there would be much less sex drive.  Geodon stays in your system for a long time.  You have to be patient with it at first, because it takes sometimes over a month to have it built up in your system.  On the other side, it is not as touchy, if you delay a dose.  It does not make you manic right away.  And tappering off or stopping will cause delayed mania later.  It does have the effect of making people super drowsy, when taken once per day.  I had to space my four pills: 1 with breakfast, 1 with lunch, 2 with supper.  With the last dose, I had to take it with supper because then I would be really tired and ready for bed about 4-5 hrs later. With the weight gain, I tried four other medicines for my mania before I went on Geodon over the time it took me from the first med to Geodon, I gained 20lbs, but stayed at that weight for the next 7 years.  Pharmacological, the only things I had to adjust were taking a cold med that was for people with high blood pressure and being careful to eat a meal when taking it in large doses or with another stomach-bleeding medicine, like Ibuprofen. I took it successfully for over seven years, until I went through the neurochemical changes of menopause.

I've been on it for going on 4 years, and I have been completely symptom free, I no longer experience debilitating lows or manic highs. I'm also a recovering substance abuser, will be celebrating 4 years of sobriety in August,Geodon helped get me sober without I think I would be dead. I use to take it with Lamtical, and was taken off of it about a year ago. I'm no stranger to stays at the  hositpal due to my condition, I use to have psychotic features that were exacerbated by my drug use. The only down side is I find it hard to cry. I cry maybe once a year if that. Most days I'm in a fairly good mood never extreme in one direction or another. This July my psychiatrist is going to be tapering off the medication. I want to see if I can handle being off of medication, if I have complications ,I have no problem going back on Geodon. Geodon has been a life saver, and I'm very thankful I was put on. Everyone's reaction will defer, so you have to see for yourself. And in no way do I recommend you go off of it without a doctor's strict supervision. Good luck!

227$Condition: Additional Medications to Treat Depression$4/16/2013 1:48:47 AM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$3$While inpatient at a psych hospital for severe depression/suicidal ideation, a doctor added a low dose of Geodon (taken in the evening) to the anti-depressants I was already on (Effexor and Wellbutrin). The first couple of nights, I was extremely tired the next morning and unable to get out of  bed the until close to lunch time. By the third day, sleeping was no longer an issue, and I felt a bit jittery. The fourth day, I felt like my heart was beating fast, and after lunch, I had a full blown panic attack - racing heart, uncontrolled sobbing, hyperventilating, sweating, muscles clenched - I have never in my life experienced a panic attack, so I can only conclude the Geodon caused it. I quit taking it, and in a couple of days, was feeling calm again. I know everyone reacts to medication differently, and it seems to help some people, but I always thought most side effects were mild - nausea, insomnia, constipation, etc. - I didn't know it could make me feel like I was going to die! It was not an experience I would wish on anyone. This is a very powerful drug and should be taken with extreme caution.

236$Condition: Bipolar Depression$1/14/2013 1:01:27 PM$Reviewer: Nyx, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$3$4$I was on geodon for a good six months if not more, and it does take an adjustment period for it to really kick in, but when it kicked in life was good, no more manic episodes of consequence and the depression evened itself out to where it would only occur every now and again. The only problem with this medication is getting off of it, the withdrawal symptoms are horrendous. Even weaning down gradually I had no sleep and headaches along with anxiety that was helped by klonpoin. And I also gained in excess of 100 lbs on this medicine that I am now working to get back off. If you are considering this drug, I would think about long term consequences of how this will affect you and if it's worth it when you eventually come off of it (some people never do and they are fine with it) For me it worked well until the weight gain and withdrawal, but it helped me while I was on it. I hope this helps someone else thinking of trying this drug!

238$Condition: Additional Medications to Treat Depression$1/7/2013 9:56:45 AM$Reviewer: Cholula8, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$1$This pill is THE DEVIL and unless you have or have had extreme bouts with psychosis and/or Schizophrenia and are institutionalised, I would strongly urge you NEVER to put this pill in your mouth.  After being on 20mg this pill for four days to help with depression and anxiety (I have never been diagnosed with Bipolar, but we were trying to discover if thats what I had), this pill induced psychosis, put me in the hospital, and gave me the movement disorders; dyskinesia, akathisia, and Dystonia. I have had to quit work, postpone school, been on disability, and have had to work with a neurologist for the past eight months to undue the damge this pill has done to me--some of which may be permanent. I know everyone experineces medicine differntly, but this pill has not been around long enough and does not have the research to back up it's claims.  If you have had problems tolerating other medications, PLEASE DO NOT take this pill. I may be in the minority when it comes to getting tons of side effects off of every pill, and I may be that one in a million for whom this pill did not work. If you could see what I have had to endure this past year, however, I think you would agree that this pill is best left for only the most severe cases. Taking this pill has been the only regret I have in life and I want to make sure no one needlessly takes this pill ever again. I wish you happy mental health and good luck if you take this pill, you're going to need it.

column1: 257$Condition: Other$8/23/2012 9:40:42 AM$Reviewer: ldlkmrwdt3
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $1$1$1$"I began taking Geodon after I was misdiagnosed as Bipolar & was on this for between 6-8 months. The side effects were horrible! If I went even an hour without my dose
column3: I would be getting what I was then describing to my doctor as ""Volts of electricity running through my brain"" I see now on here for this & other similar meds
column4: people are calling them brain zaps. My doctor said that this was not an actual side effect of the drug & that it was literally ""All in my head"" The only reason he willingly took me off of this medication despite my pleas
column5: was because my face had begun to freeze in one position. I looked as if I'd had a stroke & it took almost 6 months of being off of the Geodon before I was able to move all of the muscles in my face again. Coming off from this was terrible because of these ""Brain Zaps"" I did not know what was going on half of the time (constantly in a dazed state) & was a single mother of 2 children at the time. I am so thankful that my mother was living with us at the time to help with the kids while I dealt with all of these side effects & withdrawals. If you have a choice to take any other medication but this one
column6: my advice would be not to take the Geodon!"

column1: 261$Condition: Bipolar Disorder in Remission$7/26/2012 1:12:22 PM$Reviewer: Chaya
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$4$4$"Geodon is my miracle drug. It does not work with every body chemistry
column3: but when it does
column4: you get your life back. It absolutely crushes my mania
column5: irritability and suicidal ideations.

column1: Now
column2: side effects... oh yes. As soon as I started it
column3: I began to rock back and forth whenever seated
column4: and I still do. It makes me lactate slightly
column5: which scared the hell out of me at first. Orgasm is harder to accomplish
column6: but I'm on a cocktail so I can't solely blame Geodon (and at least I'm not a sex maniac anymore.) The really scary thing is interference with the heart's electrical impulses
column7: although it's supposedly rare. My pdoc once upped me to a total of 180mg per day
column8: G-d knows why
column9: and I promptly had an abnormal EKG and a pulse that got down into the mid-40s. After a scary week during which I told my case manager I would rather die sane than live crazy
column10: and the doctor's restoring my Geodon to previous levels (he still swears I'm the only case of that side effect he's ever heard of in real life
column11: ) my heart is all happy.

column1: When Geodon works
column2: it works well and remarkably fast. If you're willing to have a heart workup just to make sure the drug isn't going south on you
column3: I definitely recommend trying it."

column1: 328$Condition: Mania associated with Bipolar Disorder$5/28/2011 12:14:03 AM$Reviewer: friendofBill
column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $1$1$1$"I was prescribed Geodon after I checked myself into a psychiatric hospital during a severe manic episode (age 35
column3: never diagnosed before
column4: but I believe the symptoms have been present since age 11).

column1: I was on the drug for almost five years despite changing psychiatrists several times. I experienced extreme anxiety/panic attacks
column2: and would sometimes have sudden almost phobic reactions to being in crowded places that I had never experienced before.

column1: I eventually lost my job in April 2008 and have not been able to find another one; I went to rehab three times in 14 months
column2: and the third trip came when I relapsed and was put into a medically induced coma.

column1: On the third trip
column2: after almost five years on Geodon
column3: the psychiatrist switched me to Seroquel (and during those five years I had tried just quitting Geodon and found it even worse than the horrible side effects of taking it).

column1: Since switching to Seroquel in September 2010
column2: my anxiety and fears have vanished and I have no problems staying clean and sober. I now face the prospect of rebuilding a shattered career that may never recover.

column1: My advice to anyone who is given Geodon is to GET A SECOND OPINION. This is a nasty
column2: nasty drug."

column1: 363$Condition: Bipolar Depression$1/10/2011 10:09:44 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Caregiver) $1$1$1$"My boyfriend was taking geodon.  At first it was working great!  There were a few side effects.  He was sluggish in the mornings
column2: and had mild muscle aches.  Then he was told to up the dosage from 80mg a day to 160mg a day.  As soon as he did
column3: he stayed dizzy
column4: had a sense of hopelessness
column5: felt sudden dread.  This went on for 3 days.  He just sat and cried and said he didn't know what to do.  I took him to the ER because of the dizziness.  Dr. ran blood test and took a CT.  Everything came back normal
column6: so they said it was the medication and to immediately stop taking it.  We got home and everything seemed ok.  A couple of hours later
column7: the dread was back.  He started crying again repeating ""I don't know what to do
column8: I just want to die.""  I took him back to the ER and told him he was still having panic attacks and was feeling suicidal.  He is now in a mental hospital for the next 7 to 10 days.  Please be cautious when taking Geodon!  I DO NOT recommend this medication!"

column1: 364$Condition: Bipolar Disorder in Remission$1/2/2011 11:22:56 AM$Reviewer: MichaelTWarren
column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $1$1$1$"If you fully read the report
column3: notice that nearly all possibly negative side effects increased
column4: and it appears that none decreased.  Such as headache
column5: speech disorder
column6: slobering or drooling
column7: dizzyness
column8: even hemmoraging that can be extremely painful.  I am wondering why this medication is used at all?  In my situation
column9: of severe schizophrenic disorder
column10: manic depression
column11: or bipolar; my doctor seemed to expirement with ten or more prescription ""anti-psychotics"" on me.  Side effects were very troubling and long lasting
column12: some even being permanent or not going away for years.  I am wondering why this medecine is being used at all unless it is some form of euthenasia (assisted suicide).  I can't come up with the answers to these problems right here and now
column13: but I propose several problems or issued to think about.  It seems that the class of medication to treat bipolar symptoms
column14: in essence problems that become too big to handle
column15: is only punitive.  Many youngsters used alcohol and illegal street drugs to self medicate for symptoms of violent attacks or debilitating depression; in other words extreme emotional situations.  Subsequently being treated for drug addiction
column16: or symptoms of schizophrenia that were to severe to be handled by having a few beers
column17: going to a higher power or more powerful medication
column18: has thus increased side effects and damage to the human body.  After all I learned to decrease my use of any and all medications
column22: and try to treat symptoms with old fashioned methods of bed rest
column24: and probably wholesome regular nutritious meals."

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver) $2$1$5$"SEVERE CONVULSIVE REACTION TO GEODON

18 yr old son had been out w/friends all morning. His buddy brought him back to our house having a severe convulsive reaction. They thought maybe to Geodon. That seemed odd to me because he hadn't had any reactions before or had any med since last night--that I knew of.

column1: He looked like he was having a stroke or an overdose reaction to either RX or possibly illegal drugs. (The only other thing his friend admitted to was a Native American cigarette he had given him
column2: Smoky Joe. An ER nurse searched the ingredients on the internet. He found no real medical concern.)

column1: The main ER doctor is pretty certain our son‚Äôs reaction was to the Geodon
column2: based on the good response to the ""antidote"" they gave him. It was not an allergic reaction but another type. He explained the meds (which he had already been taking for 3 weeks) caused some type of misfiring of the nerves.

column1: He had been unable to speak understandably
column2: or control his muscle movements. His hands & neck  muscles were involuntarily contorted
column3: & his heart rate was dangerously high. He was having convulsions
column4: different than a seizure. He was awake
column5: alert & responsive. I guess seizures are an in-&-out reflex of the muscles. Something I hope to never have to learn more about.

column1: They were originally going to give him Cogentin to counteract the Geodon
column2: but it would take too long to get from the pharmacy
column3: so they gave him a shot of Benadryl
column4: which worked in about 30 sec. to calm him & take away all pain. Both the ER doctor & the psychiatrist say Geodon could continue to be taken in conjunction w/another medication (possibly Cogentin?)
column5: but our son didn‚Äôt want to
column6: nor did his Psychiatrist advise it. He prescribed a higher dose of Zyprexa (15 MG) to try
column7: but our son is too apprehensive about having another reaction
column8: so he chooses to take nothing & deal w/the voices.

column1: *Every person‚Äôs body make-up is different
column2: but if it's helpful to 1 person
column3: it‚Äôs worth the time to post it."

425$Condition: Bipolar I Disorder with Most Recent Episode Mixed$5/31/2010 11:22:45 AM$Reviewer: macrent2, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$4$2$Geodon is one of those very tricky drugs. It must be carefully taken and administered for proper therapeutic use. I take it for the negative side effects of my illness and it works quickly and well. However, the startup side effects are very uncomfortable and can be nasty. I was started on 60mg at night and it knocked me out and made my manic the first 3 days. After this period it made me sleepy at night and not too manic. However after about 8 hours it would clearly begin to stop working and made me agitated. So now I am on 60mg morning and 60mg after supper. It works very strangely with food. If you eat a high fat/carbohydrate meal it can make you seem a bit lethargic so I eat high fiber (fruits and veggies) and it is milder. In all it has been a lifesaver!

column11: those symptoms only happen to one in 10
column12: 000 people. He refused to take me off
column13: citing that I also wasn't taking even half the starting dose. I talked to my family doctor and after what seemed like a gallon of blood's worth of tests

column1: Throughout this time
column2: I never felt the tiniest bit less depressed

column1: My advice: If you experience severe drowsiness
column2: vertigo
column3: nausea
column4: fainting (or any other side-effect severely) stop taking it right away. Its not going to get  better. I only mentioned the largest effects of the drug on myself I didn't mention the headaches (from dehydration) or the stuttering and tremors

column1: 748$Condition: Bipolar I Disorder with Most Recent Episode Mixed$12/28/2007 9:28:34 AM$Reviewer: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$5$while talking geodone i thought i was going to die... i felt as though i needed to sleep but i couldn't i felt as though i needed to stay awake so i couldn't so i sat in the middle of my floor crying while someone else watched my kids and called my dr who said my dosage was too low they increased my dosage and i ended up in the hospital with heart arrhythmias i would NEVER recommend this drug to anyone i felt as though i wanted to die to end all the pain and discomfort and sadness it was causing me i have never had a reaction like that before and when i wrote the company they told me that does occasionally occur in some patients.....it frustrating we ask for help and get hurt more in the process and some of these meds under risks say they can lead to death i am much more cautious about what i allow drs to give me now and i am much more informer now as well bc geodoen could have killed me if i would have been alone and my kids would have had to see it happen...

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$5$5$After being diagnosed with schizophrenia in 1991
column3: my diagnosis was changed on second opinion after a severe reaction to haldol and lithium together. I've since taken every class of drug
column4: at least 40 drugs including MAOIs
column5: tricyclics
column6: SSRIs
column7: aphetamines like adderall and ritalin
column8: even hydrocodone had some limited effect
column9: but all to no avail. After reporting some psychotic symptoms to my doctor recently
column10: I was given Geodon in addition to Lamictal (somewhat helpful) I already was taking. Rather than being sedated
column11: I have more energy now and the voice is quieter and I'm less paranoid
column12: all good things. I have some hope now that I can be treated effectively after 16 years of frustration and hell.

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $5$5$4$Geodon works well to control symptoms of schizo * bipolar.  i think I have a mild case of schizoaffective which is schizo + affective (a mood disorder like major depression or mania.  I am much less agitated
column3: /w less motor activity
column4: I think clearer
column5: and I am not as paranoid or suspicious over things so much  This is the closest thing to a panacea (cure all).  My complaint
column6: though
column7: is that some doctors prescripe aggressively instead of trying to find the right dose.  The best dose is usually the lowest dose that works well.  For instance
column8: the 80 mg x 2 a day was making me very tired
column9: so i switched to 60 x2 and i am doing much beter now.  Interestingly
column10: it also helps treat OCD and tourettes
column11: although it has not been approved by the FDA for that.  My OCD symptoms are less.  I think it augments (makes greater) other drugs.
